answers.answer1: Wing tip vortices are carried by the ambient wind.
answers.answer2: Wing tip vortices have a circular and downward motion.
answers.answer3: Wake turbulence exists behind all aeroplanes and helicopters in flight.
answers.answer4: All of the above are correct.

question.qtext: The wing tip vortices generated by a heavy aeroplane can cause a lighter aircraft encountering them to

answers.answer2: continue descent even when maximum power is applied.
answers.answer3: sustain structural damage.
answers.answer4: experience any of the above situations.

question.qtext: During the two minutes after the passage of a heavy aeroplane in cruising flight, hazardous wing tip vortices will

answers.answer2: dissipate rapidly.
answers.answer3: dissipate very slowly.
answers.answer4: remain at cruising altitude.

question.qtext: The pilot of a light aircraft on final approach close behind a heavier aircraft should plan the approach to land

answers.answer1: beyond the touchdown point of the other aircraft.
answers.answer2: prior to the touchdown point of the other aircraft.
answers.answer3: at the touchdown point of the other aircraft.
answers.answer4: to the right or left of the touchdown point of the other aircraft.

question.qtext: Wake turbulence is produced by

answers.answer1: heavy aeroplanes only, regardless of their speed.
answers.answer2: turbo-jet powered aircraft only.
answers.answer3: fast moving aeroplanes only, regardless of their weight.
answers.answer4: all fixed and rotary wing aircraft.

question.qtext: Wake turbulence caused by a departing large aeroplane begins

answers.answer2: with rotation.
answers.answer3: after becoming airborne.
answers.answer4: with full power application.

question.qtext: Wake turbulence caused by a departing aeroplane is most severe immediately

answers.answer2: following take-off.
answers.answer3: above its flight path.
answers.answer4: following full power application.

question.qtext: Which statement concerning wing tip vortices is false?

answers.answer1: Vortices normally settle below and behind the aircraft.
answers.answer2: With a light crosswind, one vortex can remain stationary over the ground for some time.
answers.answer3: Lateral movement of vortices, even in a no wind condition, may place a vortex core over a parallel runway.
answers.answer4: Vortices are caused directly by ‘jet wash’.

question.qtext: Wake turbulence will be greatest when generated by an aeroplane which is

answers.answer1: heavy, landing configuration and slow speed.
answers.answer2: heavy, clean configuration and slow speed.
answers.answer3: light, clean configuration and high speed.
answers.answer4: heavy, take-off configuration and slow speed.

question.qtext: A helicopter in forward flight produces hazardous vortices

answers.answer2: similar to wing tip vortices.
answers.answer3: which remains at the same level as the helicopter.
answers.answer4: ahead of the helicopter.

question.qtext: Which statement concerning vortices caused by helicopters is correct?

answers.answer1: Helicopter vortices are generally weak and dissipate rapidly.
answers.answer2: The size and weight of the helicopter has a direct influence on the intensity of the vortices.
answers.answer3: Helicopter vortices are less intense than the vortices of an aeroplane of the same weight.
answers.answer4: Wind does not influence the movement of vortices generated by a helicopter in hovering flight.

question.qtext: What effect would a light crosswind have on the wing tip vortices generated by a large aeroplane that had just taken off? A light crosswind

answers.answer1: could cause one vortex to remain over the runway for some time.
answers.answer2: would rapidly dissipate the strength of both vortices.
answers.answer3: would rapidly clear the runway of all vortices.
answers.answer4: would not affect the lateral movement of the vortices.

question.qtext: A flight crew member aware of being under a physical disability that might invalidate licence issue or renewal shall

answers.answer2: not commence a flight as a crew member.
answers.answer3: forward the licence to the Regional Aviation Medical Officer.
answers.answer4: fly as crew member only if a back-up member is available.

question.qtext: What is the recommended treatment for hyperventilation below 8,000 feet?

answers.answer2: Hold the breath and perform a Valsalva manoeuvre.
answers.answer3: Slow the breathing rate to below 12 times per minute.
answers.answer4: Increase oxygen flow rates.

question.qtext: Damage to the ear drum in flight is most likely to occur

answers.answer2: during a descent.
answers.answer3: when using supplementary oxygen.
answers.answer4: after SCUBA diving.

question.qtext: Clearing the ears on a rapid descent may be assisted by

answers.answer2: opening the mouth widely or yawning.
answers.answer3: a Valsalva manoeuvre.
answers.answer4: all of the above.

question.qtext: Flight crew members who require decompression stops on the way to the surface when SCUBA diving should not fly for

answers.answer2: 8 hours.
answers.answer3: 12 hours.
answers.answer4: 24 hours.

question.qtext: With regard to fatigue, which statement is correct according to the information given under the “Medical Information” section of the TC AIM?

answers.answer1: Financial or family problems do not influence tolerance to fatigue.
answers.answer2: Fatigue slows reaction time and causes foolish inattentive errors.
answers.answer3: A fatigued person recuperates more quickly as altitude is gained.
answers.answer4: A fatigued person must have food immediately before and during flight.

question.qtext: A pilot who has donated blood should not act as a flight crew member for at least the next

answers.answer2: 24 hours.
answers.answer3: 36 hours.
answers.answer4: 48 hours.

question.qtext: Any pilot who has had a general anaesthetic should not act as a flight crew member

answers.answer2: during the next 36 hrs.
answers.answer3: during the next 48 hrs.
answers.answer4: unless advised it is safe to do so by a doctor.

question.qtext: Any pilot who has had a local anaesthetic for extensive dental procedures should not act as a flight crew member during the next

answers.answer2: 24 hrs.
answers.answer3: 36 hrs.
answers.answer4: 48 hrs.

question.qtext: Relatively small amounts of alcohol affect tolerance to hypoxia (lack of sufficient oxygen). This tolerance

answers.answer2: improves with increase of altitude.
answers.answer3: is not affected by altitude change.
answers.answer4: remains constant to 6,000 feet ASL.

question.qtext: Many common drugs such as cold tablets, cough mixtures, antihistamines and other over-thecounter remedies may seriously impair the judgement and co-ordination needed while flying. The safest rule is to

answers.answer1: read the manufacturer’s warning to ensure that you are aware of possible reactions to such drugs.
answers.answer2: take no medicine when you plan to fly, except on the advice of a Civil Aviation Medical Examiner…
answers.answer3: allow at least 12 hours between taking any medicine or drugs and flying.
answers.answer4: allow at least 8 hours between taking any medicine or drugs and flying.

question.qtext: The Canadian Medical Certificate of a private pilot 40 years old and over is valid, in Canada, for a period of

answers.answer2: 24 months.
answers.answer3: 36 months.
answers.answer4: 48 months.

question.qtext: The Canadian Medical Certificate of a private pilot under 40 years of age is valid, in Canada, for a period of

answers.answer2: 60 months.
answers.answer3: 48 months.
answers.answer4: 24 months.

question.qtext: The amount of fuel and oil carried on board any helicopter at the commencement of a day VFR flight must be sufficient, to provide for foreseeable delays having been considered, to fly to the destination aerodrome,

answers.answer1: and thereafter for 45 minutes at normal cruising speed.
answers.answer2: then to a specified alternate and thereafter for 45 minutes at normal cruising speed.
answers.answer3: and thereafter for 20 minutes at normal cruising speed.
answers.answer4: then to a specified alternate and thereafter for 20 minutes at normal cruising speed.

question.qtext: The amount of fuel carried on board any propeller-driven aeroplane at the commencement of a day VFR flight must be sufficient, having regard to the meteorological conditions and foreseeable delays that are expected in flight, to fly to the destination aerodrome

answers.answer1: and then fly for a period of 45 minutes at normal cruising speed.
answers.answer2: and then fly for a period of 30 minutes at normal cruising speed.
answers.answer3: then to a specified alternate aerodrome and then for a period of 45 minutes at normal cruising speed.
answers.answer4: then to a specified alternate aerodrome and then fly for a period of 30 minutes at normal cruising speed.

question.qtext: If a flight plan is not filed, a flight itinerary must be filed

answers.answer1: for flights proceeding 25 NM or more from the point of origin.
answers.answer2: only for flights in sparsely settled areas.
answers.answer3: for flights destined to land at aerodromes or places other than the point of origin.
answers.answer4: for all flights.

question.qtext: After landing from a VFR flight for which a flight plan has been filed, the pilot shall report the arrival to the appropriate ATS unit within

answers.answer2: 30 minutes.
answers.answer3: 45 minutes.
answers.answer4: 60 minutes.

question.qtext: When there is a deviation from a VFR flight plan, ATC shall be notified of such deviation

answers.answer2: within 10 minutes.
answers.answer3: within 30 minutes.
answers.answer4: within 60 minutes after landing.

question.qtext: Where no search and rescue initiation time is specified in a flight itinerary, when shall the pilot report to the “responsible person”?

answers.answer1: Within one hour after the expiration of the estimated duration of the flight specified in the flight itinerary.
answers.answer2: Within one hour after landing.
answers.answer3: Within 24 hours after the expiration of the estimated duration of the flight specified in the flight itinerary.
answers.answer4: As soon as practicable after landing but no later than 24 hours after the last reported ETA.

question.qtext: With regard to a flight itinerary, the “responsible person” means an individual who

answers.answer1: has agreed to report the aircraft overdue.
answers.answer2: is 18 years of age or over.
answers.answer3: holds an aeronautical licence.
answers.answer4: has agreed to report the arrival of the aircraft.

question.qtext: Where a VFR flight plan has been filed, an arrival report must be filed by the pilot

answers.answer2: at each intermediate stop and then reopened on take-off.
answers.answer3: by parking the aircraft in close proximity to the tower.
answers.answer4: except at airports served by a control tower in which case the controller will automatically file the arrival report.

question.qtext:
Estimated elapsed time A to B: 1 hour 15 minutes. Estimated stopover time at B: 30 minutes. Estimated elapsed time B to C: 1 hour 20 minutes.
Using the above information, what time should be entered in the “Elapsed Time” box of a VFR flight plan?

answers.answer2: 3 hours 20 minutes.
answers.answer3: 3 hours 05 minutes.
answers.answer4: 2 hours 35 minutes.

question.qtext: When filing a VFR flight plan with an intermediate stop, the total elapsed time to be entered is the total

answers.answer1: elapsed time for all legs including the duration of the intermediate stop.
answers.answer2: elapsed time for all legs, plus the intermediate stop, plus 45 minutes.
answers.answer3: flight time for all legs.
answers.answer4: elapsed time to the first landing plus intermediate stops.

question.qtext: How is an intermediate stop indicated on the flight plan form for a VFR flight?

answers.answer1: By including duration of the intermediate stop in ‘Elapsed Time’ box as ATC automatically checks time between points.
answers.answer2: Same as any VFR flight plan if the intermediate time does not exceed 30 minutes at each point.
answers.answer3: By repeating the name of intermediate stop and its duration in the ‘Route’ column.
answers.answer4: By simply indicating “Intermediate Stop” in “Other Information” column.

question.qtext: An ATC instruction

answers.answer1: must be complied with when received by the pilot providing the safety of the aircraft is not jeopardized.
answers.answer2: must be ‘read back’ in full to the controller and confirmed before becoming effective.
answers.answer3: is in effect advice provided by ATC and does not require acceptance or formal acknowledgement by the pilot concerned.
answers.answer4: is the same as an ATC clearance.

question.qtext: An ATC clearance

answers.answer1: is the same as an ATC instruction.
answers.answer2: is advice provided by ATC and does not require acceptance or acknowledgement by the PIC.
answers.answer3: requires compliance when accepted by the PIC.
answers.answer4: must be complied with when received by the PIC.

question.qtext: A pilot, after accepting a clearance and subsequently finding that all or part of the clearance cannot be complied with, should

answers.answer2: comply with only the part that is suitable.
answers.answer3: comply as best as possible under the circumstances to carry out the clearance and need not say anything to ATC.
answers.answer4: comply as best as possible under the circumstances and advise ATC as soon as possible.

question.qtext: After accepting a clearance and subsequently finding that it cannot be complied with, a pilot should

answers.answer1: take any immediate action required and advise ATC as soon as possible.
answers.answer2: comply as best as possible under the circumstances and say nothing to ATC.
answers.answer3: disregard the clearance.
answers.answer4: comply with the suitable parts.

question.qtext: An ATC clearance or instruction is predicated on known traffic only. Therefore, when a pilot is proceeding in accordance with a clearance or instruction

answers.answer1: ATC is relieved of the responsibility for traffic separation.
answers.answer2: the responsibility for traffic separation is divided between ATC and the pilot.
answers.answer3: the pilot is not relieved of the responsibility for traffic avoidance.
answers.answer4: the pilot is relieved of the responsibility for traffic avoidance.

question.qtext: If all or part of an ATC clearance is unacceptable, a pilot should

answers.answer1: comply as best as possible under the circumstances.
answers.answer2: refuse the clearance without giving a reason for refusal.
answers.answer3: acknowledge the clearance and read back only the acceptable parts.
answers.answer4: refuse the clearance and inform ATC of their intentions.

question.qtext: In an emergency requiring the use of an ELT, it should be turned on

answers.answer2: at the ETA in the flight plan.
answers.answer3: for the first five minutes of each hour UTC.
answers.answer4: during daylight hours only to conserve the battery.

question.qtext: An aircraft’s 121.5 MHz ELT may be switched to transmit for test purposes anytime

answers.answer2: during the first 5 minutes of any hour UTC.
answers.answer3: following a component or battery change.
answers.answer4: prior to flight and listening on 121.5 MHz.

question.qtext: Before shutting down you can verify that the aircraft’s ELT is not transmitting by

answers.answer1: checking that the ELT switch is in the off position.
answers.answer2: listening on 121.5 MHz for a signal.
answers.answer3: ensuring that the master switch is off.
answers.answer4: checking the ELT visual warning light.

question.qtext: All accidental ELT activations should be reported to the

answers.answer2: R.C.M.P.
answers.answer3: Minister.
answers.answer4: nearest ATS unit.

question.qtext: When an aircraft engine is left running on the ground and no person remains onboard, the aircraft’s movement must be restricted and

answers.answer1: it must remain in sight of the pilot at all times.
answers.answer2: it must not be left unattended.
answers.answer3: its gross weight must be below 4,409 LB (2,000 kg).
answers.answer4: its control locks must be installed.

question.qtext: When confronted with an approaching thunderstorm, a take-off or landing

answers.answer1: should be avoided as a sudden wind shift or low level turbulence could cause a loss of control.
answers.answer2: is safe if you can see under the thunderstorm through to the other side.
answers.answer3: should be avoided unless the take-off can be made away from the thunderstorm.
answers.answer4: is safe if the thunderstorm is regarded as light.

question.qtext: An isolated thunderstorm is in close proximity to your aerodrome of intended landing. You should

answers.answer1: land giving due consideration to wind shear on final approach.
answers.answer2: hold over a known point clear of the thunderstorm until it is well past the aerodrome.
answers.answer3: land as quickly as possible.
answers.answer4: add one-half the wind gust factor to the recommended landing speed and land.

question.qtext: The take-off thrust blast danger area includes at least that area extending back from the tail of a medium size jet transport aeroplane for

answers.answer2: 900 feet.
answers.answer3: 500 feet.
answers.answer4: 450 feet.

question.qtext: The ground idle blast danger area extends back from the tail of a jumbo jet aeroplane for at least

answers.answer2: 450 feet.
answers.answer3: 600 feet.
answers.answer4: 750 feet.

question.qtext: The ground idle blast danger area extends back from the tail of a medium size jet aeroplane for at least

answers.answer2: 450 feet.
answers.answer3: 600 feet.
answers.answer4: 750 feet.

question.qtext: The ground idle blast danger area extends back from the tail of an executive jet aeroplane for

answers.answer2: 450 feet.
answers.answer3: 600 feet.
answers.answer4: 750 feet.

question.qtext: A 45 kt blast area can be expected ..... behind the propellers of a large turbo-prop aeroplane during taxi.

answers.answer2: 80 feet.
answers.answer3: 100 feet.
answers.answer4: 120 feet.

question.qtext: ATC advises that simultaneous operations are in progress at an airport. Pilots could expect a clearance to

answers.answer1: take-off over top of an aircraft on an intersecting runway.
answers.answer2: take-off on a specified parallel runway.
answers.answer3: land and hold short of an intersecting runway.
answers.answer4: land on a specified parallel runway.

question.qtext: When issued a clearance to land and hold short of an intersecting runway, pilots

answers.answer1: shall comply regardless of the circumstances.
answers.answer2: may taxi across the intersection after the departing or arriving aircraft has cleared their path.
answers.answer3: who inadvertently go through the intersection should immediately do a 180° turn and backtrack to the hold position.
answers.answer4: should immediately inform ATC if they are unable to comply.

question.qtext: ADIZ rules normally apply

answers.answer1: only to aircraft flying above 12,500 feet.
answers.answer2: only to aircraft flying at true airspeeds of 180 kt or more.
answers.answer3: only to all southbound aircraft.
answers.answer4: to all aircraft.

question.qtext: When operating in accordance with VFR, aircraft shall be flown

answers.answer2: clear of control zones.
answers.answer3: with visual reference to the surface.
answers.answer4: in compliance with all of the above.

question.qtext: Normally, a helicopter in uncontrolled airspace at less than 1,000 feet AGL may operate during the day in flight visibility which is not less than

answers.answer2: 1 mile.
answers.answer3: 2 miles.
answers.answer4: 3 miles.

question.qtext: What distance from cloud shall an aircraft maintain when flying below 1,000 feet AGL within uncontrolled airspace?

answers.answer1: At least 2,000 ft horizontally and 500 ft vertically.
answers.answer2: At least 1 mile horizontally and 500 ft vertically.
answers.answer3: At least 2 miles horizontally and 500 ft vertically.
answers.answer4: Clear of cloud.

question.qtext: No person shall drop anything from an aircraft in flight

answers.answer1: which will create a hazard to persons or property.
answers.answer2: unless approval has been granted by the Minister.
answers.answer3: unless over an authorized jettison area.
answers.answer4: unless it is attached to a parachute.

question.qtext: A person may conduct aerobatic manoeuvres in an aircraft

answers.answer1: over an airport provided the appropriate frequency is monitored.
answers.answer2: over the suburban area of a city above 2,000 feet AGL.
answers.answer3: within Class F advisory airspace when visibility is 3 miles or greater.
answers.answer4: within Class C airspace when the visibility is 1 mile or greater.

question.qtext: CARs state that after the consumption of any alcoholic beverage, no person shall act as a crew member of an aircraft within

answers.answer2: 24hours.
answers.answer3: 36 hours.
answers.answer4: 48 hours.

question.qtext: ‘Day’ in Canada is that period of time between

answers.answer2: one hour before sunrise and one hour after sunset.
answers.answer3: the beginning of morning civil twilight and the end of evening civil twilight.
answers.answer4: the end of morning civil twilight and the beginning of evening civil twilight.

question.qtext: ‘Night’ in Canada is that period of time between

answers.answer2: the beginning of evening civil twilight and the end of morning civil twilight.
answers.answer3: one hour after sunset and one hour before sunrise.
answers.answer4: the end of evening civil twilight and the beginning of morning civil twilight.

question.qtext: Formation flying is permitted only if such flights

answers.answer1: have been pre-arranged by the pilots-in-command.
answers.answer2: are conducted above 3,000 feet AGL.
answers.answer3: are conducted by commercial pilots.
answers.answer4: are led by a pilot whose licence is endorsed for formation flight.

question.qtext: Flight through active Class F airspace with the designator CYR

answers.answer1: may be undertaken only by aircraft equipped with two-way radio communication and a transponder.
answers.answer2: is restricted to military aircraft operating under the authority of the Minister of National Defence.
answers.answer3: will be approved only for aircraft on IFR flight plans under positive radar control.
answers.answer4: is permitted only in accordance with permission issued by the user agency.

question.qtext: Which statement is correct with regard to “advisory airspace”?

answers.answer1: A transient aircraft entering active advisory airspace shall be equipped with a serviceable transponder.
answers.answer2: Non-participating VFR aircraft are encouraged to avoid flight in advisory airspace during active periods specified on aeronautical charts and NOTAM.
answers.answer3: Aircraft need to be equipped with a two-way radio to enter active advisory airspace.
answers.answer4: Only military aircraft may enter advisory airspace depicted on aeronautical charts.

question.qtext: Except as provided by CARs, unless taking off, landing or attempting to land, no person shall fly a helicopter over a built-up area or open air assembly of persons except at an altitude that will permit, in the event of an emergency, the landing of the aircraft without creating a hazard to persons or property on the surface, and such altitude shall not be less than ..... above the highest obstacle within a horizontal radius of ..... from the aircraft.
Over non-populous areas or over open water, a pilot must maintain a minimum distance of ..... feet from any person, vessel, vehicle or structure.

Except for balloons and as provided by CARs, no person shall cause any aircraft to take off or attempt to take off from, land on or attempt to land on, any surface within the built-up area of any city or town unless

answers.answer2: all obstacles on approach and departure can be cleared by a minimum of 500 ft.
answers.answer3: that surface is an airport or military aerodrome.
answers.answer4: noise abatement procedures are followed.

question.qtext: What is the height AGL above which an aircraft in VFR flight shall be operated to conform with the Cruising Altitudes Order?

answers.answer2: 2,200 feet.
answers.answer3: 3,000 feet.
answers.answer4: 3,500 feet.

question.qtext: An aircraft cruising VFR in level flight above 3,000 feet AGL on a track of 290°M shall be flown at an

answers.answer2: even thousand plus 500 foot altitude.
answers.answer3: odd thousand foot altitude.
answers.answer4: odd thousand plus 500 foot altitude.

question.qtext: The selection of a cruising altitude in the southern domestic airspace should be based on the

answers.answer2: magnetic track.
answers.answer3: true heading.
answers.answer4: magnetic heading.

question.qtext: Every person who is the holder of any pilot licence or permit shall, on demand, produce such licence or permit for inspection by persons authorized by the Minister, by peace officers and

answers.answer2: Transport Canada airport managers.
answers.answer3: immigration officers.
answers.answer4: all of the above.

question.qtext: Low Level Airspace is defined as, all airspace

answers.answer1: extending upwards from 2,200 feet AGL within designated airways.
answers.answer2: extending upwards from 1000 feet AGL within designated airways.
answers.answer3: extending upwards from the surface of the earth within designated airways.
answers.answer4: within the Canadian Domestic Airspace below 18,000 feet ASL.

question.qtext: A Control Zone normally is controlled airspace extending upwards from

answers.answer1: 2,200 feet above the surface of the earth.
answers.answer2: 700 feet above the surface of the earth.
answers.answer3: the surface of the earth to 3,000 feet.
answers.answer4: a specified height above the surface of the earth.

question.qtext: ‘Controlled Airspace’ means all airspace of defined dimensions within which

answers.answer1: Control Zone regulations are in force.
answers.answer2: security regulations are in force.
answers.answer3: Special VFR flight only is permitted.
answers.answer4: an ATC service is provided.

question.qtext: When in VFR flight within controlled airspace, a pilot must remain clear of cloud by at least

answers.answer2: 500 feet vertically and 2,000 feet horizontally.
answers.answer3: 1,000 feet vertically and 1 mile horizontally.
answers.answer4: 1,000 feet vertically and 3 miles horizontally.

question.qtext: The minimum flight visibility for VFR flight within a low level airway is

answers.answer2: 1½ miles.
answers.answer3: 2 miles.
answers.answer4: 3 miles.

question.qtext: When in VFR flight within a Control Zone, a pilot must remain clear of cloud by at least

answers.answer2: 500 feet vertically and 1 mile horizontally.
answers.answer3: 1,000 feet vertically and 1 mile horizontally.
answers.answer4: 1,000 feet vertically and 3 miles horizontally.

question.qtext: VFR cross-country pilots wishing to cross through any part of a Class C Control Zone should

answers.answer2: monitor the Approach Control frequency.
answers.answer3: advise ATC of their intentions and obtain a clearance.
answers.answer4: conform with circuit direction at that airport.

question.qtext: ATC may authorize an aircraft equipped with a functioning two-way radio to transit a Control Zone under day SVFR provided the flight visibility and, when reported, ground visibility, are each not less than

answers.answer2: 1 mile.
answers.answer3: 2 miles.
answers.answer4: 3 miles.

question.qtext: ATC may authorize a helicopter equipped with a functioning two-way radio to transit a Control Zone under day SVFR where the flight visibility and, when reported, ground visibility are each not less than

answers.answer1: 1 mile and operated at not less than 500 feet AGL.
answers.answer2: ½ mile.
answers.answer3: 1 mile.
answers.answer4: ½ mile and operated at not less than 500 feet AGL.

question.qtext: An aircraft flying in accordance with Special VFR would be flying within

answers.answer2: an Aerodrome Traffic Zone.
answers.answer3: a Terminal Control Area.
answers.answer4: an airway.

question.qtext: An arriving VFR flight shall make initial radio contact with the control tower

answers.answer1: upon entering an Aerodrome Traffic Zone.
answers.answer2: prior to entering a Control Zone.
answers.answer3: immediately prior to joining the circuit.
answers.answer4: immediately after entering a Control Zone.

question.qtext: VFR flight within Class B airspace is permitted

answers.answer1: only when the flight visibility is 5 miles or better.
answers.answer2: for all aircraft except gliders and balloons.
answers.answer3: if the pilot holds a Class B Airspace Endorsement.
answers.answer4: in accordance with an ATC clearance.

question.qtext: The pilot of an arriving VFR flight shall make initial radio contact with a control tower in Class C airspace

answers.answer1: immediately after entering the Control Zone.
answers.answer2: 10 NM outside the Control Zone.
answers.answer3: prior to entering the Control Zone.
answers.answer4: immediately prior to joining the circuit.

question.qtext: Unless otherwise authorized, a pilot on a VFR flight operating within a Class C terminal control area must

answers.answer1: exit the airspace whenever the weather deteriorates below VFR limits.
answers.answer2: establish radio contact with the appropriate ATC unit only when transiting the associated control zone.
answers.answer3: establish and maintain radio communication with the appropriate ATC Unit.
answers.answer4: contact radar service only when taking off or landing at the major airport concerned.

question.qtext: The primary objective of an aviation safety investigation into an aircraft accident or aircraft incident is to

answers.answer2: determine the adequacy of insurance regulations.
answers.answer3: enforce regulations.
answers.answer4: prevent recurrences.

question.qtext: Details on civil aviation accident reporting procedures can be found in the

answers.answer2: Canadian Aviation Regulations.
answers.answer3: Canada Flight Supplement.
answers.answer4: Aviation Safety Manual.

question.qtext: When an aircraft accident occurs, the pilot or operator of the aircraft involved shall ensure that the particulars of the accident are reported to the TSB

answers.answer2: within 24 hours by telephone.
answers.answer3: within 48 hours by facsimile.
answers.answer4: as soon as possible and by the quickest means available.

question.qtext: The TSB shall be notified of a reportable aviation accident when

answers.answer1: a person sustains serious or fatal injury as a result of being in or coming into direct contact with any part of an aircraft.
answers.answer2: an aircraft sustains damage or structural failure adversely affecting performance or flight characteristics and requiring major repair or replacement.
answers.answer3: an aircraft is missing or completely inaccessible.
answers.answer4: any of the above conditions exist.

question.qtext: The TSB considers missing aircraft to be

answers.answer2: an occurrence which need not be reported.
answers.answer3: an aviation incident which need not be reported.
answers.answer4: a reportable aviation accident.
